title-group.article-title: Algal Exudates Promote Conjugation in Marine Roseobacters

contrib-group.aff: Department of Plant and Environmental Sciences, Weizmann Institute of Science; Rehovot, 7610001, Israel

abstract.p: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a pivotal mechanism driving bacterial evolution, conferring adaptability within dynamic marine ecosystems. Among HGT mechanisms, conjugation mediated by Type IV secretion systems (T4SSs) plays a central role in the ecological success of marine bacteria. However, the triggers initiating conjugation events in the marine environment are not well understood. Roseobacters, abundant marine bacteria commonly associated with algae, possess a multitude of plasmids encoding T4SSs. Many Roseobacters are heterotrophic bacteria that rely on algal secreted compounds for supporting bacterial growth. Algal compounds therefore attract bacteria and promote colonization, including attachment to algal cells. Bacterial proximity, cell-to-cell contact, and attachment, can all foster HGT. Hence, we hypothesized that algal exudates, acting as chemoattractants for bacteria, may function as cues promoting bacterial HGT. Examination of various Roseobacters demonstrated that the genomic location of the T4SS impacts its functionality; a bacterial strain harboring a chromosomal-encoded T4SS does not perform conjugation, while a strain of the same species carrying a plasmid-encoded T4SS exhibits functional conjugation capability. Subsequently, we probed the influence of algal exudates on bacterial conjugation dynamics. Our findings revealed that algal exudates enhance plasmid transfer through conjugation but do not modulate the transcription of the conjugative machinery genes. These observations suggest that the bacterial responses to algal hosts evolved to correlate with an increased likelihood of encountering compatible partners for successful conjugation. Furthermore, since specific algae attract distinct bacterial populations, algae influence potential partners for genetic exchange and may shape the trajectory of bacterial evolution in the marine environment.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT), a key process in bacterial evolution, is the transfer of genetic material between a donor to an unrelated recipient. Bacteria, while maintaining small size genomes1, display extraordinary genetic variations that enable them extreme flexibility and adaptability1,2. The ability of bacteria to obtain fragments of DNA in one single HGT event is a driving force enabling this flexibility2. HGT allows bacteria to adapt to environmental changes by acquiring new metabolic capabilities that facilitate various abilities such as symbiosis3, antibiotic resistance4, metabolic activity5 and pathogenicity6 thereby enabling bacteria to inhabit new and dynamic niches.

Horizontal transfer of genetic material is achieved by several main mechanisms, including 1) Transformation, which is the uptake of extracellular DNA7, 2) Transduction, which is bacteriophage-mediated transfer7, 3) Gene transfer agents (GTAs), that are bacteriophage-like particles that carry random pieces of the producing bacterial genome8, and 4) Conjugation, which is the transfer of a plasmid between bacterial cells through direct cell-to-cell contact7–9. Conjugation typically occurs through the type IV secretion system (T4SS). T4SS is a versatile system found in both Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria. The T4SS facilitates cell-to-cell contact and enables the delivery of proteins and DNA between different bacterial strains, species, and even from bacteria to eukaryotic cells10. It is involved in a verity of processes such as toxin delivery, DNA release, DNA uptake, effector molecule translocation and conjugation11. The T4SS is mainly encoded by the virB operon while the virD operon carries several additional genes necessary for proper functioning of the T4SS11,12.

Many bacteria carry the T4SS genes on a plasmid, but some harbor the T4SS genes on the chromosome13–16. Plasmid-encoded T4SSs can transfer plasmids in conjugation, however the role of the chromosome-encoded T4SS is less clear13,16. Chromosome-encoded T4SSs have rarely been shown to mobilize a plasmid to a recipient strain17, and these systems are mainly involved in processes such as protein secretion, ssDNA secretion into the extracellular milieu and natural transformation14,15,18–22. Indeed, diverse configurations of the T4SS architecture exist. Interestingly, within the abundant and environmentally important Roseobacters group of marine bacteria23, many species carry T4SS genes in different genomic locations24. Roseobacters harbor T4SS genes on plasmids, chromosomes, both plasmids and chromosomes, and even on multiple plasmids within a single species (Table S1). Only the transfer of plasmids by plasmid-encoded T4SSs has been demonstrated in Roseobacters6,25,26, it therefore remains to be determined whether the genomic location impacts the function of the T4SS in these bacteria.

HGT, and specifically conjugation that was demonstrated between Roseobacters6,25–27, has been suggested as a central reason for the ecological success of Roseobacters26. These bacteria exhibit diverse metabolic capabilities and a wide range of symbiotic lifestyles28. Many Roseobacters engage in various interactions with algal hosts29–34. Algae exude various metabolites that support bacterial growth in the nutrient-poor oligotrophic ocean28,29,35. Thus, planktonic bacteria that drift in the ocean can secure a nutrient flux through proximity to an algal host. Algal exudates were shown to influence bacterial physiology28–30,35,36 and shape algal-bacterial interactions29,37. In the vicinity of algal hosts, bacteria experience spatial proximity to one another, with certain bacteria even attaching to the surface of the algal cells29,36. Previous studies have shown that bacterial proximity, cell-to-cell contact, and attachment promote HGT27,38–40. Algal exudates that attract bacteria may therefore serve as a signal that promotes bacterial HGT.

Here, we sought to explore Roseobacter conjugation in the ecological context of an algal host. Therefore, our study employed Roseobacter species that were identified in environmental samples of algae29,41. As a model algal host, we used the unicellular alga Emiliania huxleyi (also termed Gephyrocapsa huxleyi)42, which is widespread in modern oceans and was shown to harbor a rich community of bacteria, including Roseobacters29,41,43. First, we tested the ability of various Roseobacters to successfully conduct conjugation, examining the influence of the T4SS genomic location. Next, we examined the impact of algal exudates on bacterial conjugation, specifically on the expression of T4SS-encoding genes and the resulting transfer of DNA.

Examination of two bacterial strains belonging to the same species revealed that a chromosome-encoded T4SS does not lead to successful conjugation, while a plasmid-encoded T4SS is functional. Interestingly, our investigation has demonstrated expression of the plasmid-encoded T4SS genes, which did not increase in response to algal exudates. However, we have observed enhancement in bacterial conjugation efficiency and the actual transfer of plasmids following exposure to algal exudates. These observations imply that the bacterial response to an algal host is interconnected with an increased probability of encountering a compatible partner for successful conjugation.

sec.title: The P. inhibens DSM 17395 model strain is unable to act as a donor strain for conjugation
sec.p: The P. inhibens DSM 17395 model strain has been widely studied by us29,44 and by others45–47 as a representative Roseobacter strain that specializes in interactions with microalgae. To investigate the algal impact on bacterial conjugation, we first attempted to establish a conjugation assay using this model bacterial strain. The P. inhibens DSM 17395 strain harbors three native plasmids of 65 kb, 78 kb, and 262 kb, and carries all the genes that encode a complete T4SS on its chromosome (Fig. S1). In our study, a complete T4SS was defined as consisting of all the vir genes that have been previously described in conjugative Roseobacter T4SSs25,26. Interestingly, most reports on conjugation in bacteria involve plasmid-encoded T4SSs15,16,18,48, rather than chromosome-encoded T4SS. We examined and characterized the ability of P. inhibens DSM 17395 to transfer a plasmid via conjugation. To evaluate conjugation, a plasmid in the bacterial donor strain is marked with an antibiotic resistance gene, while the recipient strain is marked with a second antibiotic resistance gene on its chromosome. If the plasmid is transferred from donor to recipient, the resulting bacteria (called transconjugants) will be resistant to both antibiotics following the mating and selection process (Fig. 1A).

Since P. inhibens DSM 17395 harbors three plasmids, and the T4SS is located on the chromosome, we conducted the conjugation assay with all three plasmids as possible donors. Each of the three plasmids was marked with a kanamycin-resistance gene. As recipients, we used representatives Roseobacter strains, including D. shibae and M. algicola, that were marked with a chromosomal gentamicin-resistance gene. Our results show that under our experimental conditions P. inhibens DSM 17395 is not capable of transferring any of its plasmids to recipient bacteria (Fig. 1B). To further support this result, we conducted similar conjugation assays on agar plates instead of liquid media (Fig. 1C). Previous studies have shown that proximity, cell-to-cell contact, and attachment promote conjugation27,38–40, thus a solid surface like the agar plates should enhance the probability of plasmid transfer. Similar to the results obtained in the liquid media, P. inhibens DSM 17395 was not capable of transferring any of its plasmids to recipient bacteria during conjugation on plates (Fig. 1C). As control, all experiments were accompanied by conjugation assays with a donor-recipient pair that was previously shown to result in successful conjugation26. Our findings point to the possibility that the chromosomally encoded T4SS in P. inhibens DSM 17395 is unable to support conjugation.

sec.title: Conjugative transfer of P. inhibens P72 plasmid to various recipients
sec.p: Following the observation that the chromosome-encoded T4SS in P. inhibens DSM 17395 cannot execute conjugation, we investigated whether another strain of the same species, with a plasmid-encoded T4SS, is able to perform conjugation and act as a donor strain. The P. inhibens P72 strain carries complete T4SSs on both its 184 kb and 57 kb native plasmids, with a similar genetic organization, namely the identity and order of genes, as the chromosome-encoded T4SS in P. inhibens DSM 17395 (Fig. S1).

The 57 kb plasmid of P. inhibens P72 was marked with a kanamycin-resistance gene and was used as a donor strain in a conjugation assay with three recipient Roseobacter strains, namely P. inhibens DSM 17395, D. shibae, and M. algicola (Fig. 2A). These recipient strains were marked with a gentamicin-resistance gene on their chromosome. Several of these donor-recipient pairs were previously reported to execute successful conjugation under different experimental conditions26. Following mating and selection, all assays resulted in colonies that exhibit resistance towards both kanamycin and gentamicin. To confirm that the double-resistance colonies were indeed transconjugants, several colonies were randomly chosen from each donor-recipient pair and the presence of the acquired plasmid and recipient chromosome was validated via PCR reactions. All tested transconjugants were confirmed to be the recipient strains that acquired the 57 kb plasmid (Fig. 2B). These conjugation assay demonstrated that under the same experimental conditions, P. inhibens P72 can serve as a donor while P. inhibens DSM 17395 cannot. These observations further support a functional difference between T4SSs that are encoded on a chromosome versus on a plasmid.

sec.title: Another Roseobacter species with plasmid-encoded T4SS can act as donor via conjugation
sec.p: To investigate if another Roseobacter species that carry the T4SS on its plasmids can function as plasmid donor in conjugation, we performed conjugation assays using D. shibae as the plasmid donor. D. shibae was marked with a gentamicin-resistance gene on its 126 kb native plasmid, harboring a complete T4SS (Fig. S1). For conjugation assays using D. shibae as the plasmid donor, we selected two recipients: P. inhibens P72 and P. inhibens DSM 17395, both tagged with a kanamycin-resistance gene on their chromosome (Fig. 3A). Following mating and selection, all assays resulted in colonies that exhibit double resistance towards both antibiotics. To confirm that the double-resistant colonies were indeed transconjugants, we randomly selected several colonies from each pair and validated the presence of the acquired plasmid and recipient chromosome using PCR reactions. All tested transconjugants were confirmed to be the recipient strains that acquired a new plasmid (Fig. 3B). The conjugation experiments demonstrated that D. shibae can act as a plasmid donor for both P. inhibens P72 and P. inhibens DSM 17395. These results are in line with a previous report that used D. shibae and P. inhibens DSM 17395 under different experimental conditions and resulted in successful conjugation25. Our findings indicate that plasmid-encoded T4SSs can facilitate the transfer of plasmids among Roseobacters via conjugation.

sec.title: Expression of the conjugation machinery is evident in plasmid-encoded T4SSs and is not influenced by algal exudates
sec.p: Now that we obtained various Roseobacters that successfully perform conjugation, we wished to address our initial question and examine the algal impact on the bacterial conjugation process. First, we assessed the expression of the bacterial T4SS, under the same experimental conditions in which we observed a plasmid transfer in previous experiments (Fig. 2A, Fig. 3A). We analyzed expression levels of the T4SS genes in strains harboring plasmid-encoded T4SS, namely P. inhibens P72 and D. shibae. Both strains have two complete T4SSs on two different plasmids (57 kb and 184 kb plasmids for P. inhibens P72, and 126 kb and 191 kb for D. shibae). We assessed the expression of the T4SSs using qRT-PCR with primers that target the T4SS central genes virB4, virB8 and virD4. Each primer set was designed to assess the expression of both T4SSs in each strain. In P. inhibens P72 bacteria, virB4 and virD4 gene expression was assessed individually for each plasmid due to sequence differences (Fig. S2A). As depicted in Fig. 4A, the expression levels of virB4, virB8 and virD4 were found to be comparable to those of the housekeeping genes. This observation suggests that in the experimental conditions that supports conjugation, the T4SS genes in both D. shibae and P. inhibens P72 strains are actively expressed.

Next, we wished to evaluate the possible impact of algae on the expression of the T4SS. In the nutrient-poor oligotrophic ocean, heterotrophic bacteria rely on micro-algae as an energy source28,35,49. Algae exude nutrients and various algal metabolites that influence bacterial physiology and play a role in algal-bacterial interactions29,37. Additionally, algae serve as an attachment surface for bacteria29,36. Previous studies have shown that proximity, cell-to-cell contact, and attachment promote HGT27,38–40. Therefore, algal exudates that are sensed by bacteria may serve as a signal that promotes bacterial HGT. To explore this possibility, we examined RNA expression levels of the bacterial T4SS machinery in bacterial cultures that were supplemented with filtrates of algal cultures. These filtrates contain various algal exudates that may be sensed by bacteria. All cultures, treated and control, were supplemented with essential nutrients to eliminate the role of algal exudates in supporting growth. We evaluated the expression of the T4SS in P. inhibens P72 and D. shibae bacteria. Both strains were grown in pure cultures and qRT-PCR analyses compared expression levels of cultures that were supplemented with algal filtrates versus non-treated cultures. Analyses were performed using primers targeting the central T4SS genes, virB4, virB8 and virD4. The results demonstrated that gene expression levels are similar between untreated cultures and cultures that were supplemented with algal filtrates, for both bacterial strains. Only expression of the virD4 gene in P. inhibens P72 treated with algal filtrates showed slightly higher expression levels than untreated cultures (Fig. 4B, Fig. S2B). Collectively, these findings suggest that genes of the T4SS are constantly transcribed, with similar expression patterns to housekeeping genes, and that algal secreted compounds do not influence the expression of the T4SS machinery.

sec.title: Algal exudates enhance bacterial conjugation
sec.p: Transcription of the T4SS machinery does not seem to be influenced by algal exudates (Fig. 4B, Fig. 4D). However, transcription is not the only factor affecting the actual transfer of plasmids via the T4SS between bacteria. Therefore, we investigated whether algal exudates influence plasmid transfer between Roseobacter bacteria. To achieve this, we performed conjugation assays in which bacteria were treated with algal filtrates and compared to untreated bacteria. For the conjugation assay P. inhibens P72 and D. shibae was chosen as plasmid donors. As recipients, we used D. shibae, M. algicola, and P. inhibens DSM 17395 (Fig. 5). Our results show that conjugation assays that were supplemented with algal filtrates resulted in increased conjugation efficiency (i.e., more transconjugants per donors) compared to untreated bacteria.

Notably, algal filtrates contain substrates that promote bacterial growth28,35,49. To determine whether the increased conjugation efficiency is due to enhanced bacterial growth, we quantified donors, recipients and transconjugants in the different conjugation assays (Fig. 5, Table S2). We calculated the ratio of colony-forming unit (CFU) between treated cells and untreated cells. A ratio larger than one indicates increased growth, while a ratio smaller than one indicates inhibition of growth due to algal filtrates. We then compared the ratio of transconjugants to the ratio of donors (Fig. S3A) and recipients (Fig. S3B). Our analysis revealed that transconjugants had a higher ratio compared to both donors and recipients, indicating that treatment with algal filtrates enhanced conjugation efficiency beyond any potential growth-promoting effect.

In summary, our data suggest that while algal exudates do not affect the transcription of the conjugation machinery (Fig. 4B, Fig. 4D), they do promote conjugation (Fig. 5). The enhanced conjugation is not the result of increased bacterial growth (Fig. S3), and the underlying mechanism remains to be explored.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The current study reveals that algal exudates increase bacterial conjugation, and consequently HGT, in Roseobacters. High frequencies of HGT have been suggested to play important roles in the resilience of marine bacteria50. Since the marine environment is dynamic and rapidly changing51, the acquisition of novel traits through HGT allows marine bacteria to adapt to this dynamic environment. Various mechanisms for HGT have been observed in Roseobacters, including GTAs50 and conjugation27. Moreover, Roseobacters have many plasmids23,52, up to a dozen plasmids in a single bacterium52. Many of these plasmids harbor T4SSs39 that may facilitate conjugative HGT, potentially supporting rapid adaptation. These processes that allow Roseobacters to adapt to new niches are considered key in their ecological abundance and success23,52,53. Indeed, 27% of sequenced Roseobacters genomes harbor all genes needed for a functional conjugative T4SS (Fig. S4A). Conjugation initiation and the successful transfer of DNA was shown to be impacted by factors such as signaling molecules, temperature, cell physiology, population density, pH, and nutrients39,54,55. However, in marine bacteria, little is known about the conditions required to induce HGT, particularly conjugation. Here, we show that algal secreted metabolites promote HGT in Roseobacters.

In marine ecosystems, algae provide bacteria with nutrients28,35,49 and an attachment surface29,36. By attaching to an algal cell, bacteria can secure a steady flux of algal exudates in the algal phycosphere, which is the immediate volume surrounding the algal cell. As multiple bacteria can attach onto an algal host, they may engage in processes that require cell-to-cell contact, such as conjugation. Therefore, proximity and attachment onto an algal host may increase the chances for plasmid transfer events among bacteria in the algal phycosphere27,38–40. Indeed, previous studies demonstrated increased conjugation following attachment to abiotic surfaces56. Moreover, algal exudates support bacterial growth and metabolism57, further enhancing bacterial density, which in turn could augment the chances of bacterial HGT. Interestingly, environmental experiments with phytoplankton-derived dissolved organic matter demonstrated attraction of bacteria harboring genes for the T4SS, as shown by metagenomic analysis58. Specifically, Roseobacter bacteria often co-occur with various algal hosts in the environment and in laboratory cultures29,43,59–61. Our study demonstrates that algal filtrates increase conjugation in Roseobacter bacteria (Fig. 5), even in the absence of an algal cell for attachment. Whether a combination of algal exudates and an attachment surface further enhance conjugation remains to be studied. The current study establishes the functional link between algal exudates and bacterial HGT.

While conjugation was enhanced in response to algal exudates (Fig. 5), the expression of the conjugative machinery was not affected by algal exudates (Fig. 4B), suggesting the involvement of additional regulatory routes such as transcription of regulatory genes62 and post-transcriptional regulation. Reports on the importance of post-transcriptional regulation of the conjugative process have been previously described55 and were highlighted as a promising regulatory mechanism of conjugation63. In line with our observations, previous work has reported on substantial differences between levels of transcripts versus proteins of the T4SS, with higher transcription levels in poor media compared to rich media. In contrast, western blot of the corresponding proteins revealed elevated expression in rich media compared to the poor media64. Taken together, algal exudates may impact post-transcriptional regulation of genes involved in bacterial conjugation.

The functionality of the conjugative process appears to be affected by the genomic location of the T4SS. Various bacteria carry the T4SS-encoding genes on plasmids, chromosomes, and even on both16,17. While plasmid-encoded T4SSs are known to commonly mediate conjugation65, chromosomally encoded T4SSs rarely mobilize a plasmid to a recipient strain17. Chromosomally encoded T4SSs are mainly involved in processes such as protein secretion, ssDNA secretion into the extracellular milieu, natural transformation, and symbiosis13–16,18–22,66. Of note, within sequenced Roseobacters genomes, 23% carry only plasmid-encoded T4SSs, 2% carry only chromosome-encoded T4SSs, and 1% carry T4SSs on both the chromosome and a plasmid (Fig. S4A). Evaluating the genomic location of all T4SSs across Roseobacter genomes reveals that 86% of T4SSs are found on plasmids, 8% are located on chromosomes, and 6% cannot be conclusively assigned to a chromosome or plasmid (Fig. S4B). Therefore, chromosome-encoded T4SSs appear to constitute a notable fraction of T4SSs in Roseobacters, potentially hinting at other functions served by chromosomally encoded secretion system66. Indeed, our data demonstrate that a strain carrying a complete chromosomally encoded T4SS is unable to act as a plasmid donor in conjugation (Fig. 1B-C). In contrast, a different strain from the same species, carrying a plasmid-encoded T4SS with a similar genetic organization to the chromosome-encoded T4SS (Fig. S1), was able to serve as a plasmid donor (Fig. 2).

The origin of transfer (oriT) is a key regulatory element needed for a successful conjugation event. While a plasmid can be transferred in-trans by a T4SS apparatus, the oriT is required for DNA mobilization initiation and functions in-cis67. Therefore, chromosomally encoded T4SSs should be able to transfer plasmids that carry an oriT. Similarly, a chromosomally encoded T4SS was demonstrated to transfer an adjacent DNA fragment harboring an oriT 15. We demonstrate that under our experimental conditions the chromosomally encoded T4SS in P. inhibens DSM 17395 cannot function as a plasmid donor (Fig. 1B-C). Therefore, the P. inhibens DSM 17395 plasmids are not expected to have an oriT. However, identifying an oriT is challenging. Although some oriTs have typical characteristics, most are unknown67. Moreover, the majority of oriTs have been identified in model bacteria67–69, and knowledge on environmental strains is therefore limited. Using a web-based tool designed for identifying oriTs (oriTfinder)70, we were unable to identify oriTs on the P. inhibens DSM 17395 plasmids. Of note, when the same tool was applied to analyze plasmids that were successfully transferred in our conjugation experiments, still an oriT was not identified. These results underscore the limited molecular knowledge we currently have on key processes, such as conjugation, in environmentally abundant bacteria.

The evolution of marine heterotrophic bacteria is linked to their micro-algal hosts, as manifested by the many examples of algal-bacterial chemical exchanges that likely arose during their co-evolution29–31,44,45,71. The current study reveals the impact that algal exudates have on bacterial conjugation, which adds another layer to our understanding of bacterial evolution in the ocean. Algal exudates represent a distinct chemical signature of a given algal species72, and consequently, attract phylogenetically and functionally discrete populations of bacteria57,58,73. By attracting specific bacterial populations, algae have the potential to affect the bacterial partners that perform genetic exchange, thus possibly shaping bacterial evolution.

sec.title: Bacterial strains and growth conditions
sec.p: The bacterial strains Phaeobacter inhibens DSM 17395 and Dinoroseobacter shibae DFL-12 were purchased from the German Collection of Microorganism and Cell Cultures (DSMZ, Braunschweig, Germany) (Table 1). P. inhibens P72 was kindly provided by Prof. Juan Barja from University of Santiago de Compostela, Spain, and Dr. Jörn Petersen from the Leibniz Institute, DSMZ, Germany (Table 1). The bacterial strains of Phaeobacter inhibens DSM 17395 with a mariner transposon (Tn)-tagged chromosome, Marinovum algicola DG898 DSM 27768 with a Tn-tagged chromosome, Dinoroseobacter shibae DFL-12 with a Tn-tagged plasmid (pDSHI03, 126 kb), Dinoroseobacter shibae DFL-12 with a Tn-tagged chromosome (Table 1), P. inhibens P72 with a Tn-tagged plasmid (pP72_e, 57 kbp), and P. inhibens P72 with a Tn-tagged chromosome were kindly provided by Dr. Jörn Petersen from the Leibniz Institute, DSMZ, Germany.

D. shibae cultures were plated on ½ marine broth 2216 (MB) (Difco, USA) agar plates (MB, 18.7 g/L; agar, 16 g/L) with 30 μg/ml gentamicin antibiotic. M. algicola cultures were plated on ½ YTSS agar plates (yeast extract, 2 g/L; trypton, 1.25 g/L; sea salts, 20 g/L; agar, 16 g/L, all purchased from Sigma-Aldrich) with 30 μg/ml gentamicin antibiotic. P. inhibens DSM 17395 cultures were plated on ½ YTSS agar plates with 30 μg/ml gentamicin or 150 μg/ml kanamycin antibiotic. P. inhibens P72 was plated on ½ YTSS agar plates with 150 μg/ml kanamycin antibiotic. Transconjugants of D. shibae were plated on ½ MB agar plates with 30 μg/ml gentamicin and 150 μg/ml kanamycin antibiotics. Transconjugants of P. inhibens DSM 17395, P. inhibens P72 and M. algicola were plated on ½ YTSS agar plates with 30μg/ml gentamicin and 150 μg/ml kanamycin antibiotics.

Cultures were grown in artificial seawater (ASW) prepared according to Goyet and Poisson74. ASW contained mineral salts (NaCl, 409.41 mM; Na2SO4, 28.22 mM; KCl, 9.08 mM; KBr, 0.82 mM; NaF, 0.07 mM; Na2CO3, 0.20 mM; NaHCO3, 2 mM; MgCl2, 50.66 mM; SrCl2, 0.09 mM), L1 trace elements (FeCl3 · 6H2O, 3.15 mg/L; Na2EDTA · 2H2O, 4.36 mg/L; CuSO4 · 5H2O, 9.8 μg/L; Na2MoO4 · 2H2O, 6.3 μg/L; ZnSO4 · 7H2O, 22 μg/L; CoCl2 · 6H2O, 10 μg/L; MnCl2 · 4H2O, 180 μg/L), and L1 nutrients (NaNO3, 882 μM; NaH2PO4, 36.22 μM). The components were dissolved in Milli-Q water (IQ 7003; Merck, Darmstadt, Germany) and the pH adjusted to 8 with HCl. Stock solutions of L1 trace elements and L1 nutrients were purchased from the Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences (Boothbay, ME, USA).

Cultures of P. inhibens DSM 17395, P. inhibens P72, and M. algicola were grown in ASW medium supplemented with additional carbon (glucose, 5.5 mM, Sigma Aldrich), nitrogen (NH4Cl, 5 mM, Sigma Aldrich), sulfur (Na2SO4, 33 mM, Merck), and f/2 vitamins (thiamine HCl, 100 μg/L; biotin, 0.5 μg/L; vitamin B12, 0.5 μg/L, Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences). Cultures of D. shibae were grown in ASW medium supplemented with additional carbon (succinate, 5.5 mM, Sigma Aldrich), nitrogen (NH4Cl, 5 mM), sulfur (Na2SO4, 33 mM), and vitamins mix (adjusted from Gonzalez et al.,75 Thiamine HCl, 0.148 μM/L; biotin, 0.082 μM/L; Pyridoxine HCL, 0.486 μM/L; Nicotinic acid, 0.406 μM/L; Pantothenic acid, 0.228 μM/L; Cyanocobalamin, 0.0006 μM/L; pABA, 0.364 μM/L). Bacteria were cultivated at 30 °C under constant shaking at 130 rpm.

sec.title: Algal strain, growth conditions and monitoring
sec.p: The axenic algal strain of Emiliania huxleyi CCMP3266 (also termed Gephyrocapsa huxleyi42) was purchased from the National Center for Marine Algae and Microbiota (Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences, Maine, USA). Algae were grown in ASW supplemented with f/2 vitamins, L1 nutrients and L1 trace elements. Algae were grown in standing cultures in a growth room at 18 °C under a light/dark cycle of 16/8 h. Illumination intensity during the light period was 150 mmoles/m2/s. Absence of bacteria in axenic algal cultures was monitored periodically both by plating on ½ YTSS plates and under the microscope.

Cultures of E. huxleyi were grown as follows; algal cells concentrations from a late exponential phase culture were counted by a CellStream CS-100496 flow cytometer (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany) using 561 nm excitation and 702 nm emission. Algal cells were gated according to event size and fluorescence intensity. An inoculum of 105 algal cells was introduced into 100 ml of ASW and incubated as described above. Algal growth in cultures was monitored by a CellStream flow cytometer as described. For each biological replicate 50,000 events were recorded.

sec.title: Algal filtrates
sec.p: To obtain algal filtrates, algal cultures were grown as described above for 12 days. An initial washing of the filters was conducted by passing 100 ml ASW medium through the filter (Thermo scientific, 0.2 aPES, 250ml). Then, algal cultures were filtered, and filtrates pH was adjusted to pH 8 (Thermo Scientific Eutech pH 700 Meter) with HCl, followed by a second filtration. The ASW medium used as control was subjected to the same procedure.

sec.title: Monitoring bacterial growth
sec.p: Bacterial cultures were monitored daily by OD600 measurements using plastic cuvettes in a spectrophotometer (Ultrospec 2100 pro, Biochrom).

sec.title: Conjugation assay
sec.p: D. shibae, P. inhibens P72, and P. inhibens DSM 17395 with plasmids carrying antibiotic resistance genes were used as donor strains for conjugation. P. inhibens DSM 17395, P. inhibens P72, M. algicola, and D. shibae with chromosomes carrying antibiotic resistance genes were used as recipient strains for conjugation (Table 2).

sec.title: Pre-cultures
sec.p: Bacteria were plated on selective plates and incubated 2-4 days at 30 °C. Then, bacteria were transferred from the plates to ASW medium and adjusted to an OD600 of 0.1. Next, bacteria were diluted to an OD600 of 0.001 in the medium previously specified for each strain. Pre-cultures were grown to an OD600 of 0.3, followed by centrifugation of 10 min at 4000 rpm. Bacteria were washed with ASW and centrifuged again for 10 min at 4000 rpm. Samples were adjusted to an OD600 of 25 using ASW.

sec.title: Mating
sec.p: For each donor-recipient pair, four biological replicates were prepared for both ASW control and algal filtrates treatment. The treatment consisted of 75% fresh algal filtrates diluted in 25% ASW (v/v). Both control and treated cultures were supplemented with L1 trace elements, L1 nutrients, vitamin mix, 5.5 mM Glucose, 33 mM Na2SO4, and 5 mM NH4Cl. To each breathing tube, 2.4 ml of the medium, 100 μl of the donor strain, and 20 μl of the recipient strain were added. The breathing tubes were mixed and cultivated at 30 °C for 24 h without shaking. For the mating on agar plates, 20 μl of donor cells and 4 μl of recipient cells were mixed and plated on MB agar plates, followed by 24 h incubation at 30 °C.

sec.title: Selection and quantification
sec.p: Each breathing tube was plated in serial dilutions in two technical replicates on three selective plates: one for the donor, one for the recipient and one for the transconjugants. Plates were incubated for 48-96 h at 30 °C. Colonies were counted and quantified. Importantly, transconjugants can grow on selective plates with a single antibiotic that are used for quantifying the donors and recipients. However, our data indicated 2-5 orders of magnitude less transconjugants compared to donors and recipients. Therefore, growth of transconjugants on single-antibiotic plates is negligible in comparison to cell numbers of donors or recipients.

sec.title: Validation
sec.p: From each donor-recipient conjugation pair, 7 transconjugant colonies were re-streaked on double-antibiotics plates. After three rounds of re-streaking, single transconjugant colonies were subjected to DNA extraction using Wizard Genomic DNA Purification Kit (Promega), and the DNA was used for PCR amplification using the PCRBIO HS Taq Mix Red polymerase. For each transconjugant, three sets of primers were designed for validation: a primer set specific for the donor, a primer set specific for the recipient and primer set specific for the transferred plasmid (Table 3, Table 4).

sec.title: Quantitative Real Time-PCR (qRT-PCR)
sec.p: Pre-cultures of P. inhibens P72 and D. shibae bacteria were grown as previously described. At OD600 of 0.3, cells were harvested by centrifugation at 4,000 rpm for 10 min at room-temperature and transferred into ASW (control) and algal filtrates (treatment). The treatment consisted of 75% fresh algal filtrates diluted in 25% of ASW (v/v). Both control and treated cultures were supplemented with L1 trace elements, L1 nutrients, vitamin mix, 33 mM Na2SO4, and 5 mM NH4Cl. P. inhibens P72 cultures were additionally supplemented with 5.5 mM Glucose, and D. shibae cultures were supplemented with 5.5 mM succinate. After 30 min of incubation at 30 °C with shaking at 130 rpm, the cells were centrifuged at 4,000 rpm for 10 min at 4 °C. Cells were transferred into 450 μL of RLT buffer containing 1% β-mercapto-ethanol and kept at -80 °C until RNA extraction. RNA was extracted using the Isolate II RNA mini kit (Meridian Bioscience, London, UK) according to the manufacturer instructions. Cells were ruptured by adding low Binding Silica Grinding Beads (100 μm) (SPEX, Metuchen, Netherland) to the thawed sample and were then beaten for 5 min at 30 mHz. For further removal of genomic DNA, RNA samples were treated with 2 μL Turbo DNAse (ThermoFisher) in a 60 μL reaction volume. RNA samples were cleaned and concentrated using RNA Clean & Concentrator TM-5 kit (Zymo Research, Irvine, CA, USA) according to the manufacturer instructions. Equal concentrations of RNA were utilized for cDNA synthesis using Superscript IV (ThermoFisher), according to manufacturer instructions. qRT-PCR was conducted in 384-well plates using the SensiFAST SYBR Lo-ROX Kit (Meridian Bioscience) in a QuantStudio 5 (384-well plate) qRT-PCR cycler (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA, USA). The qRT-PCR program ran according to enzyme requirements for 40 cycles. Primers are listed in table 5. Primer efficiencies were calculated through standard curves using the QuantStudio 5 software. Gene expression ratios were analyzed as previously shown76, by geometric averaging of the housekeeping genes gyrA, and recA. To validate the absence of genomic DNA contamination, the same procedure and program were applied on RNA samples that were not reverse transcribed.

sec.title: Genetic manipulation of Roseobacter bacteria
sec.p: To insert an antibiotic resistance gene into the 65 kb plasmid of P. inhibens DSM 17395, the mutant strain ES172 (Table 1) was generated by inserting a kanamycin-resistant gene in an intergenic region between gene PGA1_RS20320 and gene PGA1_RS19930. Regions of approximately 1000 bp upstream and downstream of the intergenic region were PCR-amplified using primers 1169, 1170, 1171 and 1172, respectively (Table 4). The amplified fragments were assembled and cloned into the pYDR8 vector (Table 6) using restriction-free cloning78,79. The resulting plasmid (pYDR9, Table 6) was introduced into competent P. inhibens by electroporation. Preparations of competent cells was performed as previously described80, with slight modifications. Shortly, cells were grown to an OD600 of 0.7 in ½ YTS with 40 g/L of sea salts (also termed full salts medium). Bacteria were washed 3 times using 10% (v/v) ice-cold glycerol, centrifuged each time for 5 min at 4 °C and 6000 rpm. The competent cells were subsequently adjusted to an OD600 of 20 using 10% (v/v) ice-cold glycerol, frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80°C. Electroporation was conducted with 300 μl aliquot of electrocompetent cells, using 10 μg of DNA in a 2 mm cuvette at 2.5 V, followed by 4 h recovery in ½ YTS with full salts. The transformed cells were then plated on ½ YTSS plates containing 150 μg/ml kanamycin, and resistant colonies were validated by PCR and DNA sequencing.

sec.title: Generating the Roseobacteraceae T4SS dataset
sec.p: All Roseobacteraceae genomes (of any quality) available in the Integrated Microbial Genomes & Microbiomes (IMG/M) database81 were scanned for the presence of the virB8 gene using the IMG “Function search” tool and K03202 KEGG (Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes82) Orthology (KO) designation for VirB8. The virB8 genes (K03203) were found in 320 out of 898 Roseobacteraceae genomes. The respective scaffolds were scanned for the presence of other vir genes (virB1-B7, virB9-B11 and virD4) and were assessed as representing either plasmids or chromosomes (Table S1). Within these 320 genomes a total of 564 virB8 genes were located on 553 scaffolds. Further assignment of the scaffolds to plasmids or chromosomes was conducted using the presence or absence of plasmid operational taxonomic unit (pOTU) designation that was assigned during genome annotation in IMG and according to scaffold size. Scaffolds with no operational taxonomic unit designation larger than 300 kb were marked as chromosomes. Scaffolds with no operational taxonomic unit designation and smaller than 300 kb were marked as unknowns. Of note, the T4SS is an extremely versatile apparatus. Conjugative T4SSs typically consist of the archetypal VirB/VirD4 components (encoded by virB1-11 together with virD4). Yet, the precise number of needed genes and their essentiality for a functional T4SS remain poorly understood, particularly in non-model bacteria83–86. Consequently, due to the difficulty in predicting which T4SS is conjugative, we set stringent criteria and defined a potentially functional conjugative T4SS (i.e., complete T4SS) as one that includes all the vir genes that comprise the T4SSs located on the conjugative plasmids of D. shibae and P. inhibens P72. Accordingly, T4SSs homologous to Vir but possessing other KO assignments (e.g., Tra), that were not experimentally shown to be conjugative in Roseobacters, were not included in this analysis. In total, our analysis identified 387 out of the 553 scaffolds as carrying a complete set of T4SS genes. However, it is possible that partially complete T4SSs in our analysis or homologous T4SSs (e.g., Tra) may be functional as well15.

caption.p: A) Schematic representation of the conjugation assay. The donor strain (light blue) carries an antibiotic resistance gene (orange) on a native plasmid, while the recipient strain (grey) harbors a chromosomal antibiotic resistance gene (yellow). Successful plasmid transfer from the donor to the recipient will result in transconjugants that are resistant to both antibiotics. Results of conjugations assays performed in B) liquid media and C) on plates. Conjugation assays were carried out using P. inhibens DSM 17395 as the donor, with a kanamycin-resistance gene on one of its native 65 kb, 78 kb and 262 kb plasmids. Each donor strain was mated with recipient strains, M. algicola or D. shibae, marked with a gentamicin-resistance gene on their chromosome. As a control (“C” in the graphs), P. inhibens P72 carrying a kanamycin-resistance gene on its 57 kb native plasmid was used as a donor and mated with M. algicola or D. shibae recipients carrying a gentamicin-resistance gene on their chromosome. Dots represent individual biological replicate and lines indicate the mean value. Conjugation efficiency was calculated by normalizing transconjugant cell numbers to donor cell numbers. The title above each graph denotes Donor/Recipient.
